com.secarta.httpsec.net
Class HttpsecURLConnection

java.lang.Object
  java.net.URLConnection
      java.net.HttpURLConnection
          com.secarta.httpsec.net.HttpURLConnectionWrapper
              com.secarta.httpsec.net.HttpsecURLConnection

public class HttpsecURLConnection
extends HttpURLConnectionWrapper

Adds httpsec/1.0 authentication to java.net.HttpURLConnection. Example usage: 

HttpURLConnection = ( HttpURLConnection )new URL( "http://example.com/bob/" ).openConnection();
HttpsecURLConnection hc = new HttpsecURLConnection( c, client );
try {
  hc.setLocalID( "alice" );
  hc.setDigestRequest( true );
  hc.setDigestResponse( true );
  System.out.println( hc.getResponseCode() );
} finally {
  hc.close();
}
Note the finally block that calls hc.close(). The HttpsecURLConnection may create a file buffer. Calling close() in a finally block ensures that these buffers are deleted in case of exceptions.

HttpsecURLConnection

public HttpsecURLConnection(java.net.HttpURLConnection c,
                            Client client)
Creates a new HttpsecURLConnection.

Parameters:
c - The java.net.HttpURLConnection to wrap.
client - The Client to handle authentication.
Method Detail

getPrincipal

public HttpsecPrincipal getPrincipal()
                              throws java.io.IOException
Get the authenticated httpsec/1.0 principal or "responder" for this connection. If this method returns null it means no attempt was made to authenticate.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

setRequestDigest

public void setRequestDigest(byte[] requestDigest)
Explicitly set the digest of the request body. If you have a digest handy you can bum a couple of ticks, as long as you do setCipher( false ), and setPreemptive( true ).

getRequestDigest

public byte[] getRequestDigest()

setDigestResponse

public void setDigestResponse(boolean digestResponse)
Should we check the digest of the response? If the server doesn't send a digest we'll fail.

getDigestResponse

public boolean getDigestResponse()

setPreemptive

public void setPreemptive(boolean preemptive)
Should we send a preemptive initialize request rather than waiting for a challenge? Setting it to true will make unauthenticated responses cause an error. Setting it to false will make unauthenticated responses behave like ordinary java.net.HttpURLConnections

getPreemptive

public boolean getPreemptive()
